subject: Re: Call of Cthulhu: Typo Report: ¶6, ¶7; more name-dot confusion
msgSnippet: As a rule, I avoid dotting adjectives, even if they are the possessive of an unambiguously dotted noun. My use of Foot instead of Ooze at the end of into is
messageBody:
As a rule, I avoid dotting adjectives, even if they are the possessive of an unambiguously dotted noun. My use of Foot instead of Ooze at the end of "into" is consistent with the Manual where unabbreviated "to" is spelled with Foot. I think that Read meant for it to be used in a similar way to final It when a vowel tends to be pronounced as a high-central vowel /ɨ/ and is not stressed. What hampered Read was that phonetic manuals of the time tended not to count /ɨ/ as a vowel that existed in English. This also explains the rule to omit writing a vowel between similar sounds when writing some past participles and plurals.

On a similar note, it shows that syllabic consonants were also not well understood in Read's day. If I were to reform QS in any way, I would add a letter for /ɨ/ along with distinct letters for syllabic L, M and N.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>
> - ¶6: s/ p,/ pulpy,/
>
> ¶7:
>
> - name-dot Angell's
> - spell "pretention" as "pea row it"
> - spell "into" with final .Ooze, not .Foot
> - name-dot Webb's
> - remove namer dot on S of "A. A. S. Meeting"
> - "anthropological now as "at no thaw row utter pea utter low ox jay it key low"
> - use HTML5 <cite> on "Witch-Cult in Western Europe", "Golden Bough", and "Atlantis and the Lost Lemuria"
>
>
> So the namer-dot rules are:
>
> (1) "don't parse this for content" (Cowan)
> (2) "put one before the title of a name" (Read 8)
> (3) "don't bother repeating name dots for every word of a name" (Read 8)
>
> Let's chew on a few of the recent, mildly complicated named things, then:
>
> > "H. A. Wilcox"
> (1) gives us "H. A. ·Wilcox", while (2) given (3) degenerates to "·H. A. Wilcox".
>
> > "Providence, R.I."
> "·Providence", of course, but I still don't have a good feel for abbreviation translation other than "etc." -> "nnn". "·Providence, ·R·I" has yet to grow on me. Is there an established standard for this sort of thing?
>
> Incidentally, the best namer-dot code point is still U+00B7, right?
>
